abstract.p: Letter from Karen Copeland (Legal Action of Animals) says horses are not devoid of emotions and intelligence, as asserted by horse trainer profiled on May 31

block.p: Re ''An Unsentimental Horse Whisperer'' (Workplace section, May 31):

By printing the statement ''a horse has no emotions, no nothing, he's just a beast of burden with a little brain the size of a walnut'' as a purported professional opinion, you give credence to the type of outdated ignorance that justifies cruelty, misuse for the sake of amusement or profit, and neglect of horses and other animals in our society.
Re ''An Unsentimental Horse Whisperer'' (Workplace section, May 31):

By printing the statement ''a horse has no emotions, no nothing, he's just a beast of burden with a little brain the size of a walnut'' as a purported professional opinion, you give credence to the type of outdated ignorance that justifies cruelty, misuse for the sake of amusement or profit, and neglect of horses and other animals in our society.
Modern scientific investigation reveals that horses are highly sensitive, emotionally complex, intelligent animals, capable of a wide spectrum of feelings and sophisticated communication.

Animals do not exist merely for their utilitarian value to humans. One does not have to be ''sentimental'' to respect their right to be free from the cruelty that the endorsement of such 18th-century notions promotes.
KAREN COPELAND Kew Gardens, Queens, June 5, 2000
The writer is a lawyer for Legal Action for Animals.
